title: Palette gallery
text: flags related identities within LGBT+ community recognizable others. selected ones well-known. flags, check sections.  flag LGBT+ community, sometimes incorrectly associated gay men . Adopted 1979 revisions made original design eight stripes reduced number colors six. one ’ll see often, since encompasses everyone LGBT+ community, exceptions.  Colors derived 2018 design seven stripes, third widespread design. “Lesbian” means “homosexual woman” one known terms LGBT+ community. girlfriend can never remember side goes top positioning pins.  Sometimes “gay” synonym “homosexual”, include lesbians, palette based flag MLM, men loving men, meaning “gay”. flag inspired lesbian flag.  Originally meant “attracted gender”; gender now known spectrum (perhaps multiple spectra), meaning updated say “attracted two genders”. “Bisexual” isn’t synonymical “attracted ” anymore, “omnisexual” “pansexual” terms.  transgender person somebody whose gender doesn’t match AGAB (assigned gender birth). encompasses binary nonbinary gender identities (fact, currently nonbinary people technically transgender, since countries allow one two binary genders assigned birth). opposite “transgender” “cisgender”.  “Asexual” means “experiencing sexual attraction”. imply anything romantic tertiary attraction, asexual person may aromantic alloromantic (see “alloace”). Asexual people often nicknamed “aces”. opposite “asexual” “allosexual”, .e. orientation person experiences sexual attraction, whether bi-, homo-, hetero- .  person whose sex characteristics (phenotype, chromosomes, hormonal profile, etc.) don’t align, .e. belong binary sex (male female). characteristics don’t binary, sex characteristic spectrum. opposite “intersex” “endosex”/“perisex”/“dyadic” (personally prefer first term).  nonbinary person somebody whose gender one two binary genders, .e. woman man. Usually nonbinary identities fall inside spectrum masculinity femininity, need true enby (nonbinary person).
code: palette_lgbtq("rainbow") palette_lgbtq("lesbian") palette_lgbtq("gay") palette_lgbtq("bisexual") palette_lgbtq("transgender") palette_lgbtq("asexual") palette_lgbtq("intersex") palette_lgbtq("nonbinary")

title: Palette gallery
text: Although six-stripe rainbow flag recognizable, variants, older newer. try inclusive, others raise awareness issue. implemented ones:  2017 redesign 6-stripe rainbow flag adopted first city Philadelphia draws attention struggles people color within LGBT+ community.  2018 flag adds chevron 6-stripe rainbow flag. chevron contains black brown colors added Philadelphia rainbow flag, transgender flag colors (light blue, pink, white).

title: Palette gallery
text: lot orientations LGBT+ community belong -spectrum, whether sexual, romantic tertiary. title: Authors and Citation
text: Laura Bakala. Maintainer, author, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Bakala L (2022). gglgbtq: Show Pride 'ggplot2' Plots. https://github.com/turtletopia/gglgbtq, https://turtletopia.github.io/gglgbtq/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gglgbtq: Show Pride on 'ggplot2' Plots},   author = {Laura Bakala},   year = {2022},   note = {https://github.com/turtletopia/gglgbtq, https://turtletopia.github.io/gglgbtq/}, }

title: Show Pride on ggplot2 Plots
text: gglgbtq provides multiple palettes based flags LGBTQ community. palettes accompanied ggplot2 themes maximize readability palette (especially white strip present flags).

title: Show Pride on ggplot2 Plots
code: # Install the development version from GitHub: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("turtletopia/gglgbtq")

title: Show Pride on ggplot2 Plots
text: list available palettes, call: common use case use palettes ggplot2:  Use matching theme_lgbtq() make colors stand :  theme_lgbtq() passes additional parameters ggplot2::theme(), ’s fully customizable:
code: # Showing only the first 6 palettes (to avoid cluttering this README) head(show_pride()) ##       palettes lengths ## 1      rainbow       6 ## 2 philadelphia       8 ## 3     progress      11 ## 4     bisexual       3 ## 5      asexual       4 ## 6  transgender       3 library(ggplot2)  data <- data.frame(   group = rep(c("yes", "no", "maybe"), each = 3),   x = rep(seq_len(3), times = 3),   y = runif(3 * 3) + .5 )  ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = as.factor(group))) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +   scale_fill_manual(values = palette_lgbtq("pansexual")) ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = as.factor(group))) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +   scale_fill_manual(values = palette_lgbtq("pansexual")) +   theme_lgbtq("pansexual") ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = as.factor(group))) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +   scale_fill_manual(values = palette_lgbtq("pansexual")) +   theme_lgbtq("pansexual", legend.position = "left")

title: Show Pride on ggplot2 Plots
code: palette_lgbtq("rainbow") palette_lgbtq("philadelphia") palette_lgbtq("progress") palette_lgbtq("lesbian") palette_lgbtq("gay_man") palette_lgbtq("bisexual") # Background added to avoid the "disappearance" of the white stripe print(palette_lgbtq("transgender"), background = "gray92") palette_lgbtq("asexual") palette_lgbtq("pansexual") palette_lgbtq("nonbinary") palette_lgbtq("intersex") palette_lgbtq("aromantic") palette_lgbtq("genderfluid") palette_lgbtq("genderqueer") # Alternative version of 5-stripes lesbian flag palette_lgbtq("lesbian_7") # Alternative version of 5-stripes gay men flag palette_lgbtq("gay_man_7")

title: Show Pride on ggplot2 Plots
text: believe equal rights treatment everybody, regardless sexuality, gender identity, skin tone, nationality, features beyond human control. Thus, allow gglgbtq used project promotes hate based aforementioned factors.

what: Get one of LGBTQ palettes — palette_lgbtq
title: Get one of LGBTQ palettes — palette_lgbtq
text: Returns palette object colors based specified LGBTQ flag. Note: number colors vary palettes!

title: Get one of LGBTQ palettes — palette_lgbtq
Get one of LGBTQ palettes — palette_lgbtq
text: name character(1) Name flag colors based .

title: Get one of LGBTQ palettes — palette_lgbtq
text: lgbtq_palette object containing vector RGB color codes strings.

title: Get one of LGBTQ palettes — palette_lgbtq
text: Currently available palettes : rainbow (6 colors) philadelphia (8 colors) progress (11 colors) bisexual (3 colors) asexual (4 colors) transgender (3 colors) pansexual (3 colors) nonbinary (4 colors) lesbian (5 colors) gay (5 colors) intersex (2 colors) aromantic (5 colors) genderfluid (5 colors) genderqueer (3 colors) lesbian_7 (7 colors) gay_7 (7 colors) agender (4 colors) demiboy (4 colors) demigirl (4 colors) bigender (6 colors) alloace (4 colors) aroallo (5 colors)

title: Get one of LGBTQ palettes — palette_lgbtq
code: palette_lgbtq("bisexual")   library(ggplot2) ggplot(data.frame(x = 1:10, y = 15:6,                   group = rep(c("a", "b"), each = 5)),        aes(x = x, y = y, color = group)) +   geom_point(size = 4) +   scale_color_manual(values = palette_lgbtq("intersex"))

title: List available palettes — show_pride
text: Shows names available LGBTQ palettes metadata.

title: List available palettes — show_pride
text: data.frame palette names numbers colors.

title: List available palettes — show_pride
code: show_pride() #>        palettes lengths #> 1       rainbow       6 #> 2  philadelphia       8 #> 3      progress      11 #> 4      bisexual       3 #> 5       asexual       4 #> 6   transgender       3 #> 7     pansexual       3 #> 8     nonbinary       4 #> 9       lesbian       5 #> 10          gay       5 #> 11     intersex       2 #> 12    aromantic       5 #> 13  genderfluid       5 #> 14  genderqueer       3 #> 15    lesbian_7       7 #> 16        gay_7       7 #> 17      agender       4 #> 18      demiboy       4 #> 19     demigirl       4 #> 20     bigender       6 #> 21      alloace       4 #> 22      aroallo       5

what: Use default theme for an LGBTQ palette — theme_lgbtq
title: Use default theme for an LGBTQ palette — theme_lgbtq
text: Provides default theme given palette. LGBTQ flags contain white, default light gray background ggplot2 light. Conversely, gray dark flags yellow stripes. LGBTQ themes carefully curated palette.

title: Use default theme for an LGBTQ palette — theme_lgbtq
Use default theme for an LGBTQ palette — theme_lgbtq
text: name character(1) Name flag colors based . ... Parameters passed theme().

title: Use default theme for an LGBTQ palette — theme_lgbtq
text: ggplot2 theme object.

title: Use default theme for an LGBTQ palette — theme_lgbtq
text: Currently available palettes : rainbow (6 colors) philadelphia (8 colors) progress (11 colors) bisexual (3 colors) asexual (4 colors) transgender (3 colors) pansexual (3 colors) nonbinary (4 colors) lesbian (5 colors) gay (5 colors) intersex (2 colors) aromantic (5 colors) genderfluid (5 colors) genderqueer (3 colors) lesbian_7 (7 colors) gay_7 (7 colors) agender (4 colors) demiboy (4 colors) demigirl (4 colors) bigender (6 colors) alloace (4 colors) aroallo (5 colors)

title: Use default theme for an LGBTQ palette — theme_lgbtq
code: library(ggplot2) ggplot(data.frame(x = 1:10, y = 15:6,                   group = rep(c("a", "b"), each = 5)),        aes(x = x, y = y, color = group)) +   geom_point(size = 4) +   scale_color_manual(values = palette_lgbtq("intersex")) +   # Use the same name as for values, preferably   theme_lgbtq("intersex")

title: gglgbtq 0.1.1
text: Implemented following palettes: agender, alloace, aroallo, bigender, demiboy, demigirl. Changed gay_man gay (, analogously, gay_7). Moved palettes “Gallery” vignette.

title: gglgbtq 0.1.0
text: CRAN release: 2022-08-16 Initial version package. Added NEWS.md file track changes package.
